title: How to solve this discrete math problem - Quora

response.answer_text: Calculate [math]f(2)[/math], by substituting the value 2 into the polynomial everywhere that [math]x[/math] occurs. Do the same for [math]f(3)[/math]. You will find that one value is negative, and the other is positive. Because polynomials are all continuous, the intermediate value theorem tells you that somewhere in between, the value of the polynomial must reach zero. You’re not required to find it, just show that it must exist; that’s what the theorem guarantees. The steps above are satisfying the conditions of the IVT.

I am sure that someone will complain that this is a homework question. But I don’t care. First of all, f(x) has no holes is it and f(2)<0 while f(3)>0. How can you get from less than 0 to greater than 0 if there is no way to jump the x-axis.
